initiativeCore.problemStatement: Users need a browser-based web application to access their PC camera, view live feed, and capture photos and videos through a simple, intuitive interface.
goals: Enable users to activate their PC camera from within a web browser
Allow users to capture still photos from the camera feed in JPEG format
Allow users to record video from the camera feed in MP4 format (or WebM for Safari)
Support video recordings up to 30 minutes in length
Provide intuitive and easy-to-use interface for camera selection and capture
Support maximum available camera resolution including 720p, 1080p, and 4K
nonGoals: File formats other than JPEG (photos) and MP4/WebM (videos)
Compliance with specific regulatory frameworks (HIPAA, GDPR data retention, etc.)
Custom download folder selection by user
initiativeCore.businessImpact: Success enables users to perform basic media capture tasks directly in the browser without installing native applications, reducing friction and improving accessibility. Failure results in users seeking alternative solutions or abandoning the workflow entirely.
initiativeCore.stakeholders: Primary stakeholder: Initiative requester (self). End users requiring browser-based camera access, development team, QA team. Stakeholder approval is sufficient for launch decision.

functional.description: Application must run in modern web browsers without requiring plugins or extensions
Provide a button to request and enable PC camera access
Display live camera feed in real-time once camera is enabled
Provide a photo capture button positioned to the right side of the camera feed
Provide a video capture button positioned below the camera feed
Capture and save still images in JPEG format when photo button is clicked
Start and stop video recording in MP4 format (or WebM for Safari) when video button is clicked
Automatically download captured photos to browser's default download folder
Automatically download recorded videos to browser's default download folder
Display visual feedback when camera is active
Handle camera permission denial gracefully with user messaging
Provide a camera selector dropdown displaying camera names when multiple cameras are available
Position camera selector above the capture buttons
Support video recordings up to 30 minutes maximum duration
Prevent video recording from exceeding 30-minute limit with appropriate user notification
Display recording duration timer during video capture
Allow users to switch between available cameras using the selector
Generate file names using format: CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension (e.g., CamerApp-2026-02-10-183648.jpg)
Display error message and allow user to choose different folder when download folder is inaccessible
Cancel active recording and discard buffered data when user closes browser tab during recording
Continue recording when user switches to another browser tab (recording persists until 30-minute limit)
Request maximum available camera resolution (720p, 1080p, or 4K based on camera capabilities)
Display human-understandable error messages for all error conditions

nonFunctional.description: Camera feed must display with minimal latency (< 200ms)
Application must be compatible with Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge browsers (versions shipped from January 2025 onwards)
Interface must be responsive and usable on desktop screen sizes
Photo capture must complete within 1 second of button click
Video recording must support camera's maximum resolution (720p, 1080p, or 4K)
Application must handle camera disconnection without crashing
UI must be intuitive and easy to use with minimal learning curve
Application must work over HTTPS connections only
JPEG photos must use standard compression with reasonable quality (80-90% quality)
MP4 videos must use H.264 codec for broad compatibility (WebM/VP8 acceptable for Safari)
Application must handle 30-minute video recordings without memory overflow or performance degradation
Camera switching must occur smoothly without requiring page reload
Error messages must be clear, human-understandable, and provide actionable guidance
File naming must be consistent and sortable chronologically
Application must support browser versions released from January 2025 onwards

edgeCases: User denies camera permission
No camera device is available on the PC
Multiple cameras are connected to the PC
Camera is already in use by another application
Browser does not support MediaDevices API
User disconnects camera during active recording
User switches camera device mid-session
Insufficient storage space for video recording
Browser tab loses focus during video recording (should continue)
Browser tab is closed during video recording (should cancel and discard)
User attempts to capture photo while video is recording
Video recording reaches 30-minute maximum duration
User attempts to start new recording before previous video finishes downloading
Browser's download folder is inaccessible or has permission issues (show error, allow folder selection)
User has disabled automatic downloads in browser settings
Camera selector shows duplicate camera names
Selected camera becomes unavailable after being chosen
Browser memory limits reached during long video recording
MP4 encoding fails or is not supported by browser (fallback to WebM for Safari)
JPEG encoding produces corrupted image file
Camera supports 4K resolution but browser or system cannot handle it
File name collision when multiple captures occur in same second
User switches between tabs rapidly during recording
System clock is incorrect resulting in wrong timestamps in filenames
Camera provides resolution lower than requested maximum
Browser version is older than January 2025 releases

criteria.description: When user clicks enable camera button, browser prompts for camera permission
When camera permission is granted, live feed displays in the designated area
Photo capture button is visible and positioned to the right of the camera feed
Video capture button is visible and positioned below the camera feed
Clicking photo capture button produces a JPEG image from current feed
Clicking video capture button starts recording, clicking again stops recording and produces MP4 file (or WebM for Safari)
Captured JPEG photos automatically download to browser's default download folder
Recorded MP4/WebM videos automatically download to browser's default download folder
Application displays appropriate error message when camera permission is denied
Application functions correctly in Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge (versions from January 2025 onwards)
Camera feed displays without noticeable lag or stuttering
Application handles camera disconnection without crashing
When multiple cameras are available, camera selector dropdown appears above capture buttons
Camera selector displays recognizable camera names for each available device
User can switch between cameras using selector without page reload
Video recording automatically stops at 30-minute mark with user notification
Application successfully records and downloads 30-minute video without errors
Interface is intuitive enough for first-time users to capture photo and video without instructions
Downloaded files use naming format CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension
When download folder is inaccessible, error message displays and allows user to choose different folder
Closing browser tab during recording cancels recording and discards buffered data
Switching to another tab during recording allows recording to continue until 30-minute limit
Application requests and uses maximum available camera resolution (720p, 1080p, or 4K)
All error messages are human-understandable and provide clear guidance
Safari users receive WebM format videos when MP4/H.264 is unavailable

measurableOutcomes: 100% of supported browsers successfully request camera permissions
Zero application crashes during camera disconnection scenarios
Cross-browser compatibility verified across 4 major browsers (versions from January 2025 onwards)
100% of captured photos saved as valid JPEG files with correct naming format
100% of recorded videos saved as valid MP4/WebM files with correct naming format
30-minute video recordings complete successfully without memory errors
All downloads automatically save to browser's default download folder
100% of file names follow CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension format
Video recordings at maximum camera resolution (720p, 1080p, or 4K) complete successfully
Tab closure during recording results in 100% cancellation and data discard
Tab switching during recording results in 100% continuation until limit
All error messages rated as clear and actionable by test users

internalDependencies: Web development team availability within budget constraints
UI/UX design resources for intuitive interface layout

externalDependencies.name: MediaRecorder API with MP4/H.264 and WebM support
Canvas API for JPEG image capture
Browser vendor support for media APIs (January 2025+ versions)
Browser's download mechanism and folder access

factors: Tight timeline (next week) may limit testing and refinement
30-minute video recording may strain browser memory management
MP4/H.264 encoding support varies across browsers (mitigated by WebM fallback for Safari)
Camera enumeration and naming inconsistent across platforms
Browser download folder access may be blocked by user settings (mitigated by error handling)
Single stakeholder may result in limited user perspective (mitigated by stakeholder approval sufficiency)
4K video recording may exceed browser or system capabilities
File naming timestamp accuracy depends on system clock
Tab closure behavior requires careful event handling
mitigations: Prioritize MVP features for next week delivery, defer nice-to-have features
Implement memory-efficient video recording with chunked processing
Use WebM format as fallback for Safari when MP4/H.264 unavailable
Provide clear camera naming with fallback to device IDs
Implement user guidance for enabling browser downloads with folder selection option
Define clear scope boundaries to stay within weekly budget
Stakeholder approval confirmed as sufficient for launch decision
Use MediaRecorder API with appropriate MIME type detection
Implement progressive download for long videos to avoid memory issues
Add recording duration warnings at 25 and 29 minutes
Test 30-minute recording scenario on lower-spec hardware
Implement graceful resolution fallback when 4K unavailable
Add beforeunload event handler to properly cancel recordings on tab close
Test tab switching and closure scenarios thoroughly
Validate file naming format with edge cases (rapid captures, clock changes)
Target browser versions from January 2025 onwards for API stability
Implement clear, human-understandable error messages for all failure scenarios

deliveryIntent.rolloutExpectations: Single release next week with core camera access, live feed display at maximum available resolution (720p/1080p/4K), camera selection, and photo/video capture functionality. Files automatically download as JPEG (photos) and MP4 or WebM (videos) to browser's default download folder with standardized naming format (CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension). Support for up to 30-minute video recordings with proper tab closure/switching behavior. Error handling includes folder selection when default download location inaccessible. Advanced features like editing, filters, or cloud storage deferred to future iterations. Stakeholder approval sufficient for launch.
deliveryIntent.timelineAssumptions: Target delivery: next week (approximately 5-7 calendar days). Assumes focused development sprint with daily progress checks. Timeline is aggressive and requires immediate start, dedicated resources, and minimal scope changes. Cross-browser testing must occur in parallel with development. Testing must cover browser versions from January 2025 onwards.
constraints: Must use browser-native APIs only (no plugins or extensions)
Requires HTTPS for camera access per browser security policies
Limited to desktop PC camera access (mobile out of scope)
Dependent on user granting camera permissions
Constrained by browser API support and compatibility variations
Photo format restricted to JPEG only
Video format restricted to MP4 (or WebM for Safari)
Files must save to browser's default download folder (with error handling for inaccessible folders)
No regulatory compliance requirements to address
File naming format must be: CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension
Must support browser versions shipped from January 2025 onwards
Must request maximum available camera resolution (720p, 1080p, 4K)
Tab closure must cancel recording; tab switching must continue recording
deliveryIntent.budget: $5000 per week (confirmed for initial development week)
